selected_quotes: Renewable energy from evaporating water? Learn more about
Fascinating: Evaporation Gives Spores Energy-Generating Muscle paper here
[Nature Mag] Cientistas criam modelo de carro movido a umidade. Estudo: video

citation.abstract: Evaporation is a ubiquitous phenomenon in the natural environment and a dominant form of energy transfer in the Earth's climate. Engineered systems rarely, if ever, use evaporation as a source of energy, despite myriad examples of such adaptations in the biological world. Here, we report evaporation-driven engines that can power common tasks like locomotion and electricity generation. These engines start and run autonomously when placed at air-water interfaces. They generate rotary and piston-like linear motion using specially designed, biologically based artificial muscles responsive to moisture fluctuations. Using these engines, we demonstrate an electricity generator that rests on water while harvesting its evaporation to power a light source, and a miniature car (weighing 0.1‚Äâkg) that moves forward as the water in the car evaporates. Evaporation-driven engines may find applications in powering robotic systems, sensors, devices and machinery that function in the natural environment.
citation.title: Scaling up nanoscale water-driven energy conversion into evaporation-driven engines and generators

author.name: Txchnologist
author.description:
Txchnologist is an online magazine sponsored by GE. Every week, we offer an optimistic, but not utopian, take on the future and humanity‚Äôs ability to tackle the great challenges of our era through industry, technology and ingenuity.

We cover science and technology with an eye toward what is possible now and what will be tomorrow in renewable energy, transportation, infrastructure, artificial intelligence and other topics. Txchnologist will offer a blend of stories and visuals that communicate the ideas that will shape societies, from the developing world to our frenetic and growing cities.

Txchnologist, while sponsored by GE, takes a broader look at the world of science and technology. The stories and opinions do not necessarily reflect the views of the company.

We hope you‚Äôll join the conversation in the comments section and share our stories on Twitter, Facebook, or Google Plus.
